comments.comment_body:
I actually find it encouraging that the highly liberal, woke, movie industry cares more about the work than bowing down to the identity politics twitter mobs.

The idea that Jennifer Lopez, one of the biggest superstars of her generation, was snubbed due to being a Latinx is ridiculous. As for Little Women, not every best picture nominee gets a best director nomination. Sometimes it’s a head scratcher but it’s pretty common.

I don't see the necessity to bring race into something which is so obviously detached from that aspect of society. It's far easier to celebrate art when you're viewing it as art alone, and not some strange political ploy to 'bring down the minorities'

I'm saddened and disturbed to see the important and necessary desire for inclusion, representation and diversity to de-evolve into what we are seeing now.   I say show me a piece that isn't rightly nominated and one that should replace it and why.  Defend your decision upon the art itself.

For example, with the disgust and outrage over Stephen King's comment: I fail to see how it was so outrageous that a voter should not take into consideration identity in the matters of art?  Are we truly asking that voters view a piece of art and think to themselves "I think this piece is worthy of an award in its category, let's see who the director was...oh...nevermind, they are (choose whatever category you wish)"  

Doesn't that just sound backwards and wrong? 

Inclusion, representation and diversity are so very important, but to exclude or include based upon these matters isn't progress.

The Oscar awards should always be about the best of the best. 

Why should there always be a consolation prize Oscar placing artificial emphasis favoring "people of color" or women? Doesn't that defeat the value of an award for quality work in the first place? Why do some people place such a huge emphasis on ethnicity with pop culture awards anyway? This begs a question -- why not abolish the Latin Grammy's for its lack of inclusion?   

On any given year, the level of quality film work for Oscar contention varies, and this year, the bar is very high, i.e. with "Joker," "1917," plus one of Scorsese's all-time best. Did "Hustlers" or "Us" or "Harriett" reach that height? Why can't people look at excellence in art for its own sake?

As a card carrying voting member of the Academy of Motion

Pictures Arts & Sciences....

I am Not speaking on behalf of the Academy Members I am 

only giving a general overview of my own opinion and some 

of my decision making process....

This was a very very competitive year in most all of the 

categories, no question in my humble opinion was this one of

the toughest years...

In the category I am permitted to vote on and of course all

Members can vote Best Picture.  My category was the 

toughest...

I Did Not Look at Gender, Nor Cultural Heritage, Nor Race ,

Nor Ethnicity Etc, that Never comes into play...

I vote strictly based upon...

 "Objective Critical  Analytical Process" and ultimately I 

choose Strictly "Execution of Craftsmanship"

Unlike other awards shows where Popularity Plays into who 

Wins....But Not the Academy.... 

My personal voting choices were Nominated this year and 

rightly so, even the choices I could Not vote for, were 

included in the Nominations...

I know I have Not given much away here by design of course

To compare the Acting, Directing, Screenplay, Documentary 

Feature & Best Picture Categories, you will Objectively 

speaking SEE why these Nominations made the Cut and why 

Others simply did Not, but only if you are willing to Strictly 

and Objectively Compare the "Execution of Craftsmanship"

And the Oscar goes to...

Not until more minorities make more 5 star movies will the outcome will be different.
The odds are against minorities & lots lot men too.

Gosh these articles just hurt my soul. I am white and my wife is a person of color and I do not know anyone who openly talks like this. Maybe because it is racist?

I understand these types of articles generate clicks—I am proving it with this response—but it is willfully divisive and lazy journalism. 

If you want more Oscar nominees of color, you need better movies with actors of color. Clearly, when that happens—12 Years a Slave comes to mind— the awards follow.
The Irishman brilliantly covering mid 20th history depicting ethnic, (still not considered white enough)Irish, Italian entrepreneurs mirroring WASP privileged white Wall Street banksters.

I don’t understand why a Korean film, no matter how good, is nominated for anything other than “Best Foreign Film”. I plan to see it, but I don’t understand why the Academy is essentially promoting a foreign film in competition with American films. I cannot imagine the Academy nominating non-union films for the same reason.
Wokeness is a cultural cancer problematizing everything it touches and creating a permanent fake grievance industry.
Forget the Academy. Forget the critics. All we really need is an inclusivity app. to do the math and make the awards
The award itself is a throwback.

This sort of carping (about an industry handing out trophies to its members no less) is as silly as the complaints that arose in the Democratic primary when the public declined to support candidates that were trying to fill some identity niche. In both cases some defined group expressed their notion of merit. Everyone else is still free to have their own opinions about movies and politics.

To qualify to vote for the Oscars an individual must work in the film industry. Since these 6000 people who  win and vote are all in the same 'club' why don't they give out participation trophies? People don't watch the show a lot anymore when you can look at a list of winners the next day. You can also see the expensive outfits and the speeches that tell us to save the climate. Getting preached at by the choir. Or maybe, cancel the show. If they cancel the show, they can do a small part to help save the planet. No use of airplanes, limousines, dresses made by who?

I'm a young, spirited, female writer with 3 sisters, just like Jo March. I've looked up to her my whole life as I've read the book over and over, but watching Saoirse Ronan say Gerwig's words in that scene in the attic felt like I was looking in a mirror instead of a screen. For the first time, someone put into words how difficult it is for young independent women to make a choice between freedom and loneliness or companionship and limitation. As Jo says, "Women have minds and souls as well as just hearts." That scene was beautifully acted and directed. It's a shame that Gerwig was passed over for the directing nomination, but I hope she wins for best adapted screenplay.

“I would never consider diversity in matters of art. Only quality. It seems to me that to do otherwise would be wrong."
 - Stephen King, Voting Member of the Academy

Well said!

I have to say I normally roll my eyes at these type of articles but I watched the movie Waves and Queen & Slim￼ and I cannot believe either of them were not nominated for anything. They were easily the two best movies of the year and really make me question this process...￼

Did you know that in 1935 there were 12 films nominated for Best Picture, but only three names in contention for the Best Director award?  The awards for Best Actor, Best Director, Best Screenplay and Best Musical Score all went to THE INFORMER. No other film came close. But the Academy Award for Best Picture of the Year went to MUTINY ON THE BOUNTY, which won NO OTHER Academy Award that year!  Still, in 1935 John Ford didn't scream bloody murder because his THE INFORMER wasn't named Best Picture, and MUTINY ON THE BOUNTY'S director Frank Lloyd (hardly remembered at all today) didn't jump up and down because his Best Picture MUTINY ON THE BOUNTY didn't provide him with a concurrent Academy Award. The current AAs are almost textbook definitions of reasonableness in comparison!

It’s time to discuss white liberal racism. Well off, educated, white liberals hide behind their faux progressive politics while they quietly manipulate the system and devour the benefits. From public education to Academy Awards, their actions are playing out in plain sight. It’s time to connect the dots and see that the Academy Awards, rich white PTAs, self segregating “honors” classes and de facto segregation are all part of the same strategy. Racist liberals always blame conservatives but they are just as guilty in perpetuating this racism.
Does the quality of the performance matter anymore or just the color, gender or sex of the performer?

If you want to sort out masculinity so as to make everyone safer under patriarchy you might consider the difference between talking, acting, and being tough. Marvel that political enemies successfully labeled George H.W. Bush, of all people, a wimp, and think about why.

Define “patriarchy” in the context of a society where gender is not a tiebreaker in a dispute and women can vote, own property, choose a profession, and choose to marry or divorce. But know this. If your definition doesn’t include duties to protect, provide, and nurture then you’ve got it wrong. How often do you hear women referred to as “loafers” or “deadbeats”? Who doesn’t consider serial domestic violence or incest a terrible betrayal? (Of course both sexes have a duty to protect.)

If you want to sort this out at the movies many films from the 50s and 60s will fit the bill, from “High Noon” and “The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance” to “It’s a Mad Mad Mad Mad World” and “The Russians Are Coming, The Russians Are Coming.”

If you’re interested in the inner lives of women the films of Patricia Neal, Katharine Hepburn, Bette Davis, Vivian Leigh, Elizabeth Taylor, Frances McDormand, Cate Blanchett, Julianne Moore, and Ruth Chatterton would be a start. Granted, they’re all white.

The Oscars:
1. Run up to the stage in a crazy outfit
2. Express shock that you won
3. Begin your diatribe about sexism/Trump/global warming or whatever the crisis du jour 
4. Segue to thanking your spouse/parents/kindergarten teacher/agent, without whom you’d never be there
5. Express gratitude to your kids’ babysitter

Does it matter if it’s a rich white person or a rich black person?

The obsession with nonsense is very misplaced.

Re the article in the Education section on the University of Wisconsin, "In a Homecoming Video Meant to Unite Campus, Almost Everyone Was White":

You know, after all, it's Wisconsin. If you said that Hunter College was all white, I'd worry. 

Just so with the Oscars.

"Six of the nine movies nominated for best picture are almost entirely about white men"

And the seventh (Little Women) is entirely about privileged white women, so white, that the privileged white director had to go to Europe and Australia to find actresses to play the four sisters, because apparently American actresses aren't white enough.

But it's about women, so we're good, right?

1:48am 15 Jan

Viva tokenism!

Winning an award is absolutely lovely (or so I imagine). But its benefits to society in terms of elevating underrepresented minorities tends to be overrated. After all, there's been no "Precious 2" or "Moonlight 2." And Halle Berry still hasn't posed too much of a threat to Meryl Streep.

Even white males (boo hiss) have found their post-Oscar perks negligible. The late George Sanders complained that his win for "All About Eve" did not result in a deluge of offers. Matthew McConaughey these days is better known for his car commercials than any of his recent film roles. And when was the last time you saw an F. Murray Abraham movie?

The real ticket is to get more women and more people of color behind the camera, in the story department, and in the executive offices. That'll serve the cause of diversity in the arts a lot more than a bunch of statues.
Meanwhile, in other parts of the world, real people struggle with real problems.
A 19th century word for the 21st century: Boycott.

The Oscar nominations & the objections to their lack of DIVERSITY are, I suggest, strongly but subconsciously influenced by evolved human nature & tribalism, but because we are not supposed to be tribal in this context, we are in denial of it, by means of Orwellian doublethink. Our original tribes & nations (extended tribes) were done away with long before America was first colonised by Europeans, who had already been divided into "nation states" by their ruling elites, in order to facilitate exploitation of their populations, traditionally just as human resources & more recently also as consumers & clients of the "democratic" state & capital. The Matrix of state & capital manipulates & exploits human tribal nature, while at the same time trivialising, ridiculing or demonising it. Why is this not recognised by the academics we look to as authorities in understanding society & the state? Like their medieval predecessors and counterparts, academics are privileged clients and employees of the state, with a massive personal self-interest (largely subconscious) in rationalising and defending its role, self-image (as a nation) and ideologies (social, political, economic etc.), on which it bases its claim to moral and knowledgeable authority. The analogy, loosely applied, with the film, The Matrix, is a very useful one, I think: https://twitter.com/rogerahicks/status/1045233491875713024?s=20

Stephen King rarely gets much right these days, but he was spot on yesterday.  I imagine the good Liberal readers of the times prefer something like "Affirmative Action" for the Arts.  I feel exactly the same regardless of whether it's used for College Admissions or Awards - it's wrong.

With the rise of Netflix and more diverse outlets for distribution, in all arts, it will be a slow climb--but eventually there will be more representation.  The important thing is, as consumers, is to support these endeavors with our money, our time and our support.  Hollywood or any other entertainment mecca isn't going to change unless we as consumers change.  We must support the arts that we believe in: rather than react we must be more proactive in our desire to have more voices heard.  

To arm chair quarterback the Oscars, the Grammys or whatever artifice we choose to be outraged at isn't the way.

Having grown up in the NY area, I know that Westchester Country Club and Winged Foot Country club don’t exactly hand out memberships to minorities.  I’ve always thought the same thing about the nominations made by the Academy.  Why do the nominations surprise people every year.  This is who the Academy is.

My own feeling is that "Little Women" would have ended up with additional nominations (possibly including Best Director) had it opened a month or so earlier.  Same goes for the performances of Jamie Foxx in "Just Mercy" and of Alfre Woodard and Aldis Hodge in "Clemency." Lupita Nyong'o was amazing in "Us" but horror films don't ordinarily receive Oscar nominations ("Get Out" notwithstanding).  "The Farewell" was a small, overrated indie, and Jennifer Lopez is too much a publicity hound to be taken seriously as an actress (she was pretty much typecast in "Hustlers" and Academy members probably want to see her "do it again" albeit in a riskier sort of role).  In any case, Oscar has spent the last few years honoring movies with black subjects and black actors in leading roles (including the maudlin "Green Book").  This year, that happens not to be the case.  Fault movie executives for spending so little time and money greenlighting original projects that would appeal to intelligent viewers of all races and ethnicities.  Oscar voters have, on the other hand, generally done their best with the material they've been offered for year-end appraisal.
The Academy was allowed to nominate up to 12 films (9 made the cut), but only the standard five directors.  Simple math might tell you where  Little Women ranked in the 9 nominated films.
This again?

Awards shows where the rich and famous pat themselves on the back for something that really doesn't matter in the long run are so trivial now.  Oscars have always been "very male, very white".  Who really cares?  We have a crazy man sitting in our Oval Office, Australia is burning, war is a real threat, and a kook in Korea is is itching to play with his missiles.  The Oscars are tiny and superficial compared to real issues.  Think they're "too male and too white"?  Turn off the television and do something better with your time.  The Oscars haven't been interesting in a long while anyway.

(1)Several years ago the Academy expanded the slots for Best Picture from 5 up to 9-10 nominees, depending on the individual year. The same should be done for the Best Director category as well; keeping it as five really deprives many noteworthy directorial achievements that should  be remembered in the nominations; also, movies don't direct themselves: a year with 9 best picture nominees shouldn't have only 5 best director nominees; (2) the Academy should also expand the acting categories by 1-2  more actors whenever the initial results for  5th, 6th and 7th are very close. The Emmys often have 6-7 nominees in certain categories, depending on the  particular year, often in the supporting acting category. This should also be the case for the Oscars. (3)  Truthfully, I didn't see what made Florence Pugh's perf. supporting actress worthy. It was good work but  not really Oscar level. Jennifer Lopez gave an exceptional performance and should have gotten Pugh's  slot. Lopez did  memorable work in a highly enjoyable, well executed film. 
(4)  also remember TAXI DRIVER: for the 1977 Oscars, Martin Scorsese didn't even get a Best Director nomination, even though the film  had 4 noms, including Best Picture.The film today is recognized as one of the greatest American films of the 1970's, and is on the AFI's 100 greatest films of all time. Scorsese's slot was given to a woman--Lina Wertmuller for directing the film, SEVEN BEAUTIES, which no one really remembers today.

"Harriet" is an abomination and Erivo's poor performance shouldn't have been nominated for anything.  Can we please stop with the term "people of color?"  What does that mean anyway?  Erivo is a black British/Nigerian, Jennifer Lopez is a white Hispanic and "Awkwafina" is a white Asian (as contrasted to Aziz Ansari, a nonwhite Asian).

'Very Male, Very White' could have been said about the Oscars 50 years ago. I was surprised to learn today that in 92 years there have been a total of 5 Oscars given to women for Best Director. So nothing new with racist and sexist elements but the intensity seems to have acquired a toxic edge that currently permeates our culture. Blame is easy and solutions are complicated.  If there is upset about racism and sexism at the highest levels of entertainment and celebrity imagine the personal abuse, insults and exclusions delivered upon minorities and women every single day by the millions.  At 70, I am disappointed in the evolutionary progress of modern humans in the most modern culture on earth. Perhaps humans are failing and we just can't get past our blind denial.

Americans have been dabbling with socialist policies - á la carte - for most of our history. Examples include countless public works projects such as the Hoover dam, the WPA, the federal reserve, the postal service, the transcontinental railroad, the atomic bomb, the US highway system, ARPANET (precursor of the world wide web), medical advancements, and many more. These "socialist" projects have not only been good for America, they have have been fundamentally transformative.

Currently the US tax payers subsidize corporate risk by providing tax subsidies and other goodies. 

What many people don't realize about Sander's brand of policies is that it is not merely socialist redistribution of wealth, but - more accurately stated - a redistribution of speculative risk. Our most successful government initiatives have succeeded by absorbing enormous risk and capital expenditure in order to jump start entirely new industries. Such expenditures and coordination are nearly impossible for even the wealthiest private companies. Redistribution of the risk to all US tax payers is essential for a modern thriving economy if it is to maintain competitiveness in the global market. It is also, as it happens, essential for solving our most significant issues of the day that include health care and planetary "therapy" for reducing climate change impact.

Sanders' loves socialism and his pet cause is socialized medicine.  Care should be taken to distinguish between socialized medical insurance versus socialized medical care.  Socialized insurance is where the government owns and operates the insurance company (like Medicare).  Socialized medical care is where the medical care facilities are owned and operated by the government with doctors and other personnel being employees of the government (like the VA hospital system).  Generally, socialized medical care also incorporates socialized medical insurance.  Sanders sees socialized insurance as an interim step to socialized medical care.

Do you recall the scandal of the VA putting patients on extremely long waiting lists for services, so long that some were even dying of their condition before they ever got treatment? And those poor billionaires who have enjoyed tax cut after tax cut even as they employ firms of accountants to ensure they end up paying nothing, how will they live on a few million less? 

No, I’m sorry, but social justice will just have to wait. For shame, Brett Stephens.

The great wild card is Bernie's health. He has the money, the groundswell of support and the charisma. 

But he hasn't won the Nomination yet and there is still a great deal of battle left and much mettle and stamina will be required. Can his health hold out? Will he become fatigued as the campaign continues? 

The longer the battle for the Nomination continues, Mayor Pete's age actually becomes more and more of an asset, as the driver of his tireless energy. 

Notice that Biden has largely been conserving energy by carefully limiting his campaign stops. Biden and Bernie are around the same age, and I worry that Bernie is going too hard in this great marathon battle for the Nomination. 

I personally believe that despite his flaws, the Nomination is still Biden's to lose, but time will tell.

Because most of current America's political culture was forged during the fifty years of cold war with the Russian empire; the Socialism phobia is embedded in our culture.  The truth  is that socialism, like capitalism, is simply an economic model.  All the  deficiencies come in their applications.
Yes, the Soviets chose the model of socialism for their economy, but the applications were mostly flawed by the corruption that comes with human nature.  Similar critiques can be made of capitalism. Ever wonder why most of the countries considered "great places to live", all have significant social welfare policies?
There is nothing evil  or sinister about socialism.  The bad comes form the misapplication of socialism by evil governments.

It amazes me the amount of people who are so divisive over the thought of a "socialist" president. What has capitalism given you? What bothers me about Sanders' supporters is that they intentionally ignore his age. If you can't see the difference between Trump and Sanders, or Trump and Warren, something is wrong with you.

Sure, don't support them in the primary if their stance doesn't perfectly mesh with yours, but if one of them ends up with the nomination, I hope that any sane person could see past differences and vote for them.

Yes, I prefer Bernie's ideas ... and I believe then can and should be integrated into our political policies and future.

If we unseat Trump.

Bloomberg is the way to go.......can take on Trump head to head as no one else can...

I like Mike !!

It’s a bucolic environment that’s great for the visitor but is something entirely different when seen up close....and that’s my exact feeling of Bernie as president.

A female in my 60's and definitely not a Bernie Bro.  Also a lifelong democrat that is fed up with the way the party has strayed from its roots. I'm one of the bluest Democrat one could find. Yet, after seeing the recent events with regard to Bernie and Warren (and seeing what happened in 2016), if Bernie gets the nomination, my family and my extended family will stay home in November.

I agree with Bret's grasp of the political moment. I am generally a centrist, but will be voting for Bernie. 

 My theory is that Trump has taken us to a place where a return to normalcy is no longer going to work. Income inequality and the corruption of all levels of society by business is too severe. Business actors use the country's cultural differences to help them divide the middle and lower classes.  But today's awful political climate is ultimately driven by economic fear.  Trump is the backlash to years of inequality, and it's not going to stop, so let's backlash with Bernie and get something useful out of it. The whole country, business included, will benefit from a national health insurance solution, improved food security, and aggressive climate change policy. In this political system with its gerrymandered Koch-sponsored Republican candidates, we have to have someone as radical as Bernie to eventually get us to where Buttigieg and Klobuchar want to start. Gail, I resent your comment that women will look at Sanders' intensity and not like it because it reminds us of a bad boyfriend. Please don't perpetuate the notion that women only look at male candidates through the lens of their romantic relationships; it's a tired, sexist trope. 

We can handle someone who is intense--whether it's Sanders or Warren--and can evaluate them according to their policy positions, just as men can.

No, a vote against Sanders AND Trump is not a vote for Trump.  It is a meaningful exercise of my right to say - via my vote - that I do not endorse the politics and rhetoric of either candidate.  

Why?  Because as much as I abhor Trump and want to vote for a Democrat, I will not trade one extreme for another.  Sure, Sanders would at least comport himself better than Trump, but the prospect of his election has all the makings of a political and social civil war in this country.  That folks, we do not need.  We need a reconciliation, not a sharpening of the divide between right and left.  Sanders cannot do that nor does he want to do that.  He wants to burn down the house to fix the plumbing, and that I cannot support.

It makes them approach the job of President as radical reformers instead of as chief executives serving the entire population as that population has agreed by consensus. That is where they will, either of them, lose their ability to actually achieve what they want in a form that suits the needs they seek to address.

Politics is the art of the possible and all lasting changes have been compromises. Liberal democracy is compromising and settling for the best that can be achieved. The kind of changes that completely change society for real are often thought to require some kind of destruction of the old to enable the new to begin, but in fact they always occur gradually, never all at once.

The US could be crippled by cyber hacks in a matter of minutes without a shot being fired.  And I have read that we are vulnerable, . President Eisenhower notably commented in this matter: "Every gun that is made, every warship launched, every rocket fired signifies, in the final sense, a theft from those who hunger and are not fed, those who are cold an not clothed. This world in arms in not spending money alone. It is spending the sweat of its laborers, the genius of its scientists,  the hopes of its children." When will we ever learn?

About once a year we visit relatives north of Fort Worth. It’s interesting to see the area develop. I presume Alliance Airport is the main driver of growth. There appears to be a virtuous cycle of new warehouses and manufacturing, local government property tax revenue invested in local infrastructure, new decent housing for people working the new middle and lower middle class jobs, and new McMansions for people in management.

I’d like to see ever more efficient engines in the jets and trucks that help make all that work, but otherwise I don’t want to advocate for policies that would mess things up for those people.

So, Bret: at some point I think it’s incumbent on you and folks who think like you to explain to the rest of us the circumstances under which taxes and regulations make life generally better for just about everyone without killing the goose that lays the golden egg, and when the costs of the taxes and regulations exceed the benefits or the burden falls unfairly and disproportionately on some people.

Does all that development north of FW  evaporate if we tax carried interest as ordinary income, tax capital gains (other than in tax advantaged retirement accounts) as ordinary income, or regulate the financial sector more like we used to?

Gail Collins claims that Sanders long ago "actually had a good record of getting bipartisan support for his legislation". This is the official Sanders myth, based on the fact that during his 12 years in the House had 17 amendments he had authored pass the House by roll call vote. The first time I heard about this, it seemed fantastic. Over 90% of House members never ever author even one amendment that goes to a full roll call vote, much less that passes. Sanders has bragged about this for decades. 
Only recently did I research what had really happened, starting with the frequently cited (including by Sanders supporters, who seem not to have read it all) Rolling Stones article that called Sanders the King of Amendments. The point of that article was that committees still ruled the legislative process, and that NOT ONE of Sander's amendments ever made it into the bills passed by the House. They passed because everybody in the House knew they were just grandstanding, and meant nothing. In fact, sometimes Sanders traded his critical procedural votes in committee for these nothingburger amendments.

And that depends on how comfortable your room is, how much of your paycheck you have to pay for the rent on your room and how close you are to getting evicted for missing a rent payment when your old car breaks down. It also depends on whether you realize that your Social Security check, your unemployment check (yes, people still lose their jobs through no fault of their own), and your Medicare and Medicaid coverage are "socialism."  

It's too much to ask that corporate farmers getting subsidies, disaster "relief," and bailout checks, and health insurance corporations getting tax-paid premium subsidies can be understood as a form of "socialism." If one of these corporatists wins the nomination, not only will the country but also the planet will be destroyed as well. A return to a presumed "status quo" is absurd, impossible. Unless people recognize the permanent harm that the military-industrial complex has wreaked upon this world and work to reverse that harm, we are doomed. To argue as Stephens does that we need to keep investing in a strong military to counter Russian or Chinese aggression, for example, is the specious logic of someone whose short-term vision, paradoxically leads to long-term chaos: famine, floods, fires, the migrations of millions who will destabilize geopolitics and cause much suffering in untold military conflicts based on whatever land grabs ensue when there is little livable land left. I would like to support Sanders.  But in spite of all of the talk about illegal immigration, I still don't really understand his position on illegal immigration.  Maybe readers of the NY Times know the answer to this conundrum.

There are two positions on illegal immigration and many other positions which are in between or more extreme.

1.  One might favor open borders.

2.  One might favor humane treatment of illegal immigrants, but more restrictions on immigration intended to keep the US population from growing further, coupled with aid to foreign countries (such as Guatemala) which have suffered immensely because of too much population growth.

The problem with the first policy is that it is based upon innumeracy.  Population of Guatemala has quadrupled since 1960.  Currently, Guatemalan population is increasing by about 350,000 per year.  Thus we need to  inaccept 350,000 immigrants per year JUST FROM GUATEMALA to keep up with population growth.

The result of open borders is likely to be no universal health care for the foreseeable future even if one confiscates the wealth of the billionaires.  Try to confiscate the wealth and the stock market would likely fall destroying the wealth before it is collected.  And cashing in stock certificates does not immediately provide the trained doctors one needs to provide universal health care.

In other words, open borders is inconsistent with addressing the other problems America faces, the increase in homelessness and despair.

Senator Warren lost the chance to be taken seriously by me when she said there was no point in running if you did not intend to change a bunch of stuff. This is both logically and politically flawed.

We cannot have a government so big and so ingrained in what the private sector does that companies spend more on lobbying than they do on making better products and services.

A fine example is our subsidies of natural gas-powered cars with electric motors. Some rich people have bought them as status symbols and taken thousands of public dollars to do, but most people have decided to pass. Now some are pushing to extend those subsidies even though they have had the effect of having many companies put electrified cars on the market. 

This would be a shift from helping an industry get off the ground to dislodge a status quo (a valid role of government) to forcing a specific outcome no matter what consumers want or what the negative side effects are. In the latter economic model, if a company succeeds in selling dubious claims about the virtue of their products to members of Congress this can short-circuit the desire of consumers. This describes not a market, but a centralized economy working in slow motion, and that will rarely end well.

Unfortunately, many in government cannot recognize this distiction or simply prefer not to, and Senator Warren seems to be among them.

A note to Mr. Stephens and other conservative friends who believe Trump should not be re-elected, but are willing to vote only for some of the Democratic candidates and stay home otherwise: In a close election, not voting or voting for a third party candidate is effectively voting for the eventual winner of the poll. Assume candidates A & B are running, and you don't vote because you don't like either of them, but if you had to choose you would vote for candidate B. If A gets 1000 more votes than B, but there were 2000 voters like that who would choose B. By not voting this block has effectively elected A. If they go out and vote, B wins and they have elected B. In either case they will pick the winner. So let's say Warren becomes the Democratic nominee, you have to be honest with yourself and pick 4 more years of Trump or 4 years of warren, hold your nose and go out and vote! 

Here's another thing to consider. If Bernie or Warren win, they won't be able to enact their agenda unless they have a supermajority in Senate and can overcome all legal challenges hurled at them (Obamacare is still in legal jeopardy). Key Points •Transform our energy system to 100 percent renewable energy and create 20 million jobs needed to solve the climate crisis. •Ensure a just transition for communities and workers, including fossil fuel workers. •Ensure justice for frontline communities, especially under-resourced groups, communities of color, Native Americans, people with disabilities, children and the elderly. •Save American families money with investments in weatherization, public transportation, modern infrastructure and high-speed broadband. •Commit to reducing emissions throughout the world, including providing $200 billion to the Green Climate Fund, rejoining the Paris Agreement, and reasserting the United States’ leadership in the global fight against climate change. •Invest in conservation and public lands to heal our soils, forests, and prairie lands. •End the greed of the fossil fuel industry and hold them accountable. https://berniesanders.com/en/issues/green-new-deal/

I thought Sanders was a Johnny-one-note hammering constantly on fixing income inequality as the panacea for all of the United States' problems until recently I became acquainted with Zach Mortensen's Feb 20, 2018 article on why ALL the gun control ideas won't work to reduce gun homicides won't work. All but one: Reducing income inequality. Mortensen's careful study and regression analysis predicts that if virtually all of Canada's gun control policies are applied in the US, each one's effect on our gun homicide rate will, counter-intuitively cause an INCREASE, rather than a decrease. So why is Canada's rate so much lower than ours? Only one factor was statistically significant at lowering gun violence and homicide. Despite a lower median income, Canada's income inequality rate is so much lower that it overcame ALL the other negatives. Mortensen extrapolated the effect on gun homicides if the US lowered its income inequality to Canada's rate. The result was STUNNING! Of the roughly 16,000 gun homicides (non-suicides) in 2017, all but roughly 1,000 would be eliminated! (he didn't study the effect on suicides--24,000 by guns, 23,000 by other means but it's reasonable to suppose similar reductions.) So Bernie Sanders' "cure-all"--solving income inequality, would be THE best way to reduce gun violence after all! https://zachmortensen.net/2018/02/20/your-gun-control-ideas-wont-work-this-one-will/

In April 2016, Indiana’s U.S. Senators sent a bipartisan letter to the federal office responsible for printing government documents, asking that the word “Hoosiers” be the official word to describe Indiana natives.

According to a style manual from the U.S. Government Publishing Office, those who live in Indiana are “Indianans.” That office produces and prints documents for all three branches of the federal government.

Republican senator Dan Coats and Democratic senator Joe Donnelly sent a letter Tuesday urging the use of “Hoosiers” instead.

The senators say newspapers in the state have been using the term since 1826. They also quote a poem from Richmond poet John Finley that they say normalized the term. The poem is called “The Hoosier’s Nest.”

I have a confession to make.  I was raised a Seventh-day Adventist.  My mother told me the earth is only 6000 years old.  So I visited the Grand Canyon.  And it looked like the canyon was cut by the Colorado River.  But the Colorado River could not have cut the canyon in 6000 years.  So I rejected creationism.

Then I went to the university.  And I found that the sciences made sense but not so much the social sciences.

In particular, macroeconomics appeared fraudulent.  (Not microeconomics of course.)

The reason was the models were based upon human behavior.  People could choose to disobey the economic rules.  That's different from the planets which are FORCED to follow Newtonian mechanics.

And the statistics used by economists seem fraudulent.  Take GDP for example.  It doesn't include the effects of global warming which may drive humans to extinction!

So why does the wealth tax look fraudulent?  Because it imagines that the wealth of billionaires can be transformed into medical care.

The famous painting Salvator Mundi by Leonardo sold for $450 million at auction.

But how do you transform that into medical care?  Wouldn't the price fall?

The stock market is now in bubble territory.  Isn't there a danger that a wealth tax (if implemented) would lead to a market crash, preventing the wealth from being collected?

Structurally the Iowa role seems all wrong. But in terms of democracy, I've begun to see it differently. We tend to forget the evidence that groupthink fails, that our current partisan landscape is driven by social cohesion. Democracy works when individuals think for themselves, gather their own facts, and decide without influence of others. If this sounds impossible today, or ever, it's a matter of how much. Iowans are able to hear candidates in person, not mediated, and they aren't keen on going with the group. Whether by accident or not, they seem to gravitate towards the ideal approach: thinking for themselves.

The founding parents of the US Constitution debated whether a big country could be democratic, when historical examples were city-states. Madison argued that size was good, because isolated groups would cancel each other's special interests. Sort of worked. But there's still something to be said for smaller populations doing democracy. Let's accept this accident of history until America matures more.

As an interested voter, however, I would advocate for scrapping the primary system altogether and returning to a system, still used in Europe, in which the political parties in the United States nominate presidential candidates at nominating conventions (preceded perhaps by state nominating conventions). Actually, that's how the smaller parties in the United States such as the Libertarian Party operate.

Registered members of political parties (not voters registered with a party) should convene to pick party leaders, including candidates for public offices. Political parties should represent a platform and candidates from those parties should be chosen to present that platform to the voters.

The primary system has had its day. Voters would be better served by parties choosing their candidates at conventions designed for that purpose, just as was once was done in the United States and still does occur in Europe.

As a native of Iowa (born and raised, in Steve King's district no less), I find it absurd that a small, non-representative state has so much power every four years. Since the Iowa Caucuses began in 1972, most of the Democratic winners have gotten the party's nomination. However a quick look shows that most of them would certainly have been nominated had those caucuses not been held. For the Republicans, Iowa is often used by a fringe candidate spending all his time, money and staff there. Six Republican winners there have gotten the nomination, three of them sitting Presidents and one Vice President. 
There is a military saying that a battle doesn't decide who's right, but it surely decides who's left. So it will be with Iowa this year. Most Democratic candidates seem to be running in hopes of being chosen Vice President or to a Cabinet position, or maybe to gain recognition that will be useful in four years. Anybody not finishing in the top five in Iowa will lose those possibilities. It will be similar in New Hampshire. 
Today there are four Democratic candidates who in Iowa and nationwide consistently favored by 10 to 25 percent of the electorate, in most recent polls more like 15 to 20 percent. The rest score less than 5 percent, but there are so many of them that their total number of supporters is significant. Until the field winnows down, who wins in Iowa will not affect who gets the nomination.  But who loses will have a significant effect.

This is just one more example of why the present situation in the US, re primaries (and caucuses) and elections are problematical.
50 states, 50 sets of rules, none simple, all complex in some way or another and extending over too long a period of time.
Hard to imagine who thought out this system.
It was not the Founding Fathers as they made no constitutional provision for primaries.

Democrats allocate their delegates proportionately among candidates who get 15 percent or more of the vote in a given state or district. If the polls are accurate, you're looking at a four-way race through New Hampshire at least. Iowa will serve to knock practically everyone else out of the race. However the basic primary mechanics won't change. Sanders, Biden, Warren, Buttigieg.

You can imagine a scenario where Warren or Buttigieg unexpectedly fails to hit 15 percent. However, probably not both. You'd end up with a three-way race with one side or the other consolidated. In that sense, Iowa could decide the primary again. The consolidated side would have a clear path to victory. Only the 3rd candidate dropping out would make the race competitive again.

Bloomberg might make Iowa irrelevant though. Assuming at least a relatively split Iowan vote, Bloomberg challenges whichever establishment candidate that survives. Even if Biden manages to knock Buttigieg out of the race or vice versa, establishment Democrats still enter Super Tuesday with a split ticket. If both candidates survive, there will be a three-way split.

Progressives really only need a consistent showing in both Iowa and New Hampshire. One candidate against the establishment. The path from there is relatively clear. At the moment, that candidate looks like Sanders. However, I'm beginning to sense hostility from the Warren camp. The progressives may end up cannibalizing themselves after all.

The argument here is based on a false premise. It is just assumed that "unity" is good. It is, but I'd also argue that it is actually not that important. Winning the Presidency is purely a matter of electoral college math. 

Unified or divided, Democrats simply will win Oregon. And Republicans simply will win Wyoming. Etc. This is a polarized nation. In fact in probably 80% - 85% of the states everyone already knows who the winner will be. 

This election, like the last one, will not be someone that "unites" the party at the nation level, but rather will be won by whomever takes that small handful of swing states that are in play. So the real question is - who can win them?

And in that respect, I'm not sure Warren is all that strong. The winner will need states in particular in the south east, and northern Midwest. Michigan? Usually solidly Democratic, in fact every election since 1992 - until Trump. She'd need it back. 

But it has unionization levels above the national norm, many of who's members have really good medical benefits from labor negotiations. Unions play a huge roll in the day to day work of organizing and getting out the vote - and telling them they are going to toss out their hard won benefits and just participate in medicare for all is not exactly the way to enthuse them.

Just an example - point is, "who can unite the national party" is an irrelevant question. "Who can win the swing states" is the only question that matters.

"We have met the enemy, and he is us." Walt Kelly, "Pogo." I still feel that the biggest problem facing the Democrats are the Democrats themselves. Trying to appeal to the "true believers" of progressive socialism on one end, to moderates  who range from liberals to Obama-Trump independents on the other is one thing. Then they have to negotiate the  "minefield" between identity politics and economic policies. A party that tries to be "everything for everybody" runs the risk of becoming "nothing for nobody." Against all this is the potential of four more years of Trump, should the Senate not convict him.  It's a tall order to fill for whomever emerges at the end of the process.

As for Ms. Warren? She may well get the nod, but her ideas (or Sanders too, for that matter) are very far left and will have to fight a hurricane strength onslaught from the Republican side to win in November. The thing the Democrats need to avoid is make 2020 seem like a repeat of 2016. Any candidate who makes Trump, even with all we know about him now, still seem to be the "lesser of the evils" may give it a good shot, but it will be long odds for success.

I think the way to think about this is to recognize that our parties are not monolithic, but are, instead, coalitions or alignments.  Consider Israel, for example.  In that country, there is a right wing coalition that includes a large mainline Conservative party (Likud), and a number of smaller religious and nationalistic parties.  The problem there is that none of the individual parties can win enough votes to govern on its own, and so there is a period of horse trading after each election in order to cobble together the majority coalition needed to govern.

Where we differ from Israel is that the political horse trading takes place before the election by way of the primary and caucus system.  One way to look at Clinton’s defeat in 2016 is as an inability to build the required governing coalition.  She just couldn’t get one or two tiny parties to sign on.

There’s nothing wrong with partisan factionalism prior to the convention.  I’d argue that having a transparent period of political horse trading is a good thing for democracy.  That horse trading serves to moderate extreme candidates who seek leadership as they strive to accommodate the various groups they’ll need to govern if they win.  The good thing is that because the coalition building happens before the election, we all have a better idea of what policies we’ll get if our candidates win.

The one payer system will win every time. Insurance frictional cost is unnecessary. Insurance is to protect against risk. I have had mixed feelings about this field of candidates. After failing to generate too much heat with attacks on Mayor Pete’s “wine cave” fundraiser, Warren’s surrogates were on the lookout for the next big thing to attack, and latched onto a memo that: A) apparently doesn’t emanate from the top of the Sanders campaign; and B) is empirically true - eg: the Warren campaign doesn’t have as much appeal to prospective new Democratic voters.

It is factually true that, overall, the Sanders and Warren demographics are different: that Sanders has attracted more lower income and less educated voters who, as a demographic, vote less; and that Warren gets more higher income professionals who vote more.

Saying this is not an attack, but must be squarely faced, because it bears on the critical question of Sanders' vs. Warren's electability:

Simply, a higher % of higher income Warren supporters will vote for any Democratic candidate; whereas a lower % of lower income Sander supporters will vote for other Democrats - because only Sanders' economic populism (combined w/his 'beer track,' authentic working class character) have politically engaged many of them.

A lot of potentially Democratic-voting US citizens stay home - a Sanders candidacy promises to get more of them to the voting booth.

First, there are those that believe winning in 2020 requires winning the center, which means nominating a candidate who appeals to moderates, Independents and disenchanted Republicans, while holding steady to core Democratic principals.    

Second, is the camp that believes focusing on the center is a fools game and the path to victory is "energizing" the progressive base and turning out more minority and young voters.  

It seems like very few people believe that both can be accomplished under any of the candidates still running.  Warren and Sanders more clearly appeal to the progressive left, while Biden and Buttigieg appeal to the center-left.

Where the progressives fall down is (1) on the lack of widespread appeal of progressive ideology, in particular in swing states, and (2) the actual value of turning out more Blue voters in already Blue states.  

I know the progressives here will take umbrage with these points and it's very early to be making predictions, but I can't help but keep going back to the fact that Bernie's support is consistent but he's never polled above 26% support among Democrats, let alone ALL VOTERS, and Warren's campaign is flagging thanks to her gaffes on M4A and campaign donations from corporations.  If these two candidates can't beat Joe Biden in the polls then that should tell us all that it isn't quite the time for the Democrats to be pushing a progressive platform to win a national campaign.

1) I will vote for the Democratic nominee, no matter who it is.

2) I will volunteer to canvas in the fall, as I did for President Obama in 2012 and, to my regret, did not in 2016 for Hillary Clinton.

Democrats can win this election. But all who can must do more than be willing to simply pull a lever (figuratively, in this age of sketchy digital voting). We must all, to the best of our abilities, give time, money and energy to ensure that people vote Democratic. We cannot afford to let apathy or Facebook/Russian-driven schisms keep people on the couch.

I know we live in an era when everything just sort of floats into our homes, from entertainment (Netflix) to products (Amazon). Most of the comments against EW refer to Medicare for all as a divisive subject because it would be disruptive. This position is a defeatist attitude ensuring to a republican win in November.
Most Democrats, in fact most Americans, would like to see a rational, cost saving health care system. To reach this goal, the new system will have to reduce profits for health providers, pharmaceutical companies and eliminate the current system of private health insurance. 
What Americans want is to be able to choose their doctor. Medicare, which already exists shows us how to reach that goal.
So, the health care industry has started to fight back arguing that it is about choice, confusing insurances with providers. When is the last time anyone truly chose their health insurance provider? Has it ever led any non millionaire to be able to choose any doctor they want. This is spin coming from an industry fighting for its survival.
So instead of recognizing the spin for what it is, some Democrats look at some polls and see that change is not going to come without a fight, and they give up fearing such change would be too disruptive. 
No significant change will ever come without being disruptive. Change comes if people are ready to accept that there will be losers and they are going to be vocal. That is what politics is about. Refusing disruption is to insure a republican win in November in whatever form it will take, including a weak democratic administration.

This means not only is my employer setting the terms for my insurance, it is on the take for both premiums, my medications, taking the deductible right out of my pay before any coverage kicks in--and determining what healthcare it decides I can't have all to it's direct advantage and against me.

I love Bernie, but this kind of anti-trust raping of the American worker is something I trust to Warren who has spent a lifetime understanding corporations and sees the light on just how far they are willing to go to crush the individual.

On this one, Warren is the ONLY candidate to show any understanding of it at all, let alone has a plan for it.

It isn't just about healthcare, it's about everything a corporation can do in this country either. When will people wake up to what republicans have unleashed on this country?

While I read and agree with Michelle Goldberg regularly, I disagree with this column.  Her husband does work for the Warren campaign -- a clear compromise to Michelle's impartiality.  The column's claim that Warren is a "unity" candidate is simply not true -- whether among Democrats or the American electorate in general.  Warren's Medicare - for - All is highly divisive.  Because Warren recognizes the divisiveness of her medicare plan, she has back off from pushing it on the campaign trail.  Except for Sanders, Warren stands with the other leading contenders for "weak" support, not the strong support claimed by Michelle. Warren's candidacy -- contrary to the article's claim -- would exacerbate factionalism.  Some of Warren's statements and implications put off many of us who might otherwise support her.  Implying that those who do not agree with her are afraid and lacking in imagination is one example.  Finally, Michelle leaves out one huge element -- winning back those voters who twice voted Obama, then voted Trump.  They number six million.  Clearly there are other candidates who can appeal to these voters far, far better than Warren -- Buttigieg and Klobuchar to name two.
Another way to look at this is, who is the most likely to lose to Trump? According to Rick Wilson it's Sanders. He might be right.

That said, Warren, who is one of the most qualified to run, hasn't yet unpacked the Trump lies and insults that still haunt Hillary and throw Republicans into hissy fits  
of epic proportion.  Her propositions strike fear into the hearts and minds of those forever resistant to change, even if that change can benefit them.

It is true that Warren has tries to be all things to all people.  She wants to please the people who want health care and at the same time please the people who don't want to pay for it. 

I will vote for her if she gets the nomination , but my concern is that her personal story has too many contradictions and that Trump will be able to effectively use this against her if she ever faces him in a debate.

This election will be a slog, but I believe that any of the current Democratic candidates has the capability to win if they run a great campaign. 

What I think about more is the day after Inauguration Day 2021. Which of the Democrats has the best shot then for an approval rating above 60 percent? 

My gut says that Warren doesn’t get us there. I think Mayor Pete has the best chance to break the deadlock of the culture war that is tearing this county apart. And his husband will mean a great deal to families like mine. This Life-Secular Faith and Spiritual Freedom (author information at the end).

There are three major problems with this analysis. 

First, a series of polls suggests that Biden voters favor Sanders as their second choice. Even if other polls lead to Warren, clearly the first set of polls suggest that Biden voters are open to Sanders.  Collectively therefore we can conclude that given that Biden is the most conservative of the major candidates and Sanders is clearly the least conservative (notwithstanding Sanders hope for conserving the ecological system), Sanders is a unity candidate.  Therefore, the preposition "the" in the original article is misplaced.

Second, the article says nothing about Republican or Independent voters and whether Warren as opposed to Sanders can win these over.  What about those who tend not to vote and how Sanders might win them over through his populist appeal?  Thus, the word "unity" by restricting itself to the Democratic Party is missing the larger and most important context for "unity of voters."

Third, to the extent this article is widely cited and read it creates a self-fulfilling prophecy.  The more one says that Warren is "the" unity candidate, the more it is so.  Therefore, one wonders what the difference is between "opinion" and "advocacy" in a newspaper column.  Perhaps we need a new section of the paper called "advocacy."

In my pre-retirement career as a public opinion survey designer and analyst at Michigan State's Institute for Public Policy and Social Research I conducted surveys which looked at all factors related to how people tend to vote. There were several personal characteristics where self-identified Republican and Democratic respondents differed from each other: Republicans favored older candidates; Democrats favored candidates from less wealthy backgrounds; Democrats were more likely to consider a female candidate. 

There was only one personal characteristic favored by 97% of the respondents, with no discernible differences as a function of political party. That was honesty. People want to believe what a candidate says.

In separate national polling in 2016, the only candidate of all the contenders who scored lower than Donald Trump, who was rated as honest by 32% of respondents, was Hillary Clinton, at 27%. In addition to that, she came from a wealthy background, was certainly not youthful, and she had been a supporter of Barry Goldwater. But all that aside, she had a  history of shading the truth and, like Trump, never conceded that she had done so.

In the coming election, Donald Trump will face an opponent who, unless it is Biden, will not have a national track record of truthfulness to attack. But Elizabeth Warren is not youthful and has altered her plans without giving credible reasons for doing so. 

Given the advantage of incumbency I think Warren will lose to Trump.

I want to write about the catastrophic McGovern loss to Nixon in 1972, in light of comments I have seen from fellow commenters who are skeptical of EW chances.

I recently finished reading Nixon biography and how he successfully captured post civil rights white anxiety (“the forgotten men and women” and the “silent majority”) and turned the deep south red for over a generation. Only now, decades later, parts of the Deep South are showing signs of turning blue under the pressure of demographic change.

It is a mistake to pin the McGovern loss on only his progressive politics. There were these very strong under currents at play back then in this Vietnam / post Civil Rights era. And 1972 was the year when the Deep South did turn red. This was a much bigger trend than just McGovern and people who keep bringing that up are drawing the wrong lessons.

EW peculiar politics (“progressive capitalist”, populist and technocrat rolled into one) may be a fit for today’s changing politics. Fast increasing inequalities, middle class financial stress, hunger for right o left populism, drop of support for traditional free trade and internationalist engagement. It may be that EW is the right candidate now.

Is she the best choice out there? I don’t know. But she is my personal choice and her intellect, stamina, seriousness, moral compass and working class roots will make her a great president.

Dear Men:
I hope you can try your best to appreciate what it is like for women like me, who, for the very first time, see our experiences and our struggles reflected and understood in such a deeply resonate way, by a candidate like Elizabeth Warren. Like Warren, many of us fought hard against a system that told us to step aside and trust others to know what was best for us, but we prevailed, often demoralized, always resilient.  In her hard won success and life-long fight for others, we see our best selves. And now, not a news cycle goes by where it isn't explained to us that we once again need to step aside and put our trust in a more moderate, male candidate who is better equipped to beat trump, not because they are the better candidate, but because somehow Warren is "unelectable".  Please don't underestimate her, and please don't underestimate the passion she can generate among folks like me.

Tellingly, you twice cite a poll that explicitly surveyed "Democratic primary voters."  Senator Warren brings to the table  a brain that sees the whole picture as well as the experience and training to develop an organization that actually researches, plans and functions. There are two kinds of unity—between progressive and centrist politicians, and between the multi-racial working class, youth, minorities, women, urban and rural voters. Recently, Elizabeth Warren positioned herself as the unity candidate between Democratic politicians, two-step Medicare-for-all, praise from Obama, moderate positions on the Bolivian coup and Suleimani assassination. Her polls have stalled. Warren has been moving left since the ‘90s. Is she the struggling Oklahoma teacher, Republican Ivy League professor, reformist Senator regulating banks, or progressive committed to the working class? 
Trump has 40% of American voters sewed up, unlikely to either grow or shrink, and he could win the electoral college again.
Warren’s “I have a plan” is that of a well-meaning, top-down technocrat, appealing to the white urban professional class. She can’t lead the democratic mass movement of rallies, unionization, and community organizing, energize those turned off by the uncaring political system to go to the polls, and win over white workers focused not on perceived racial interests but on economic justice—all things we need to pass legislation. 
Bernie and Biden have bases in the working class and minorities. Who can energize the people, steal Trump’s thunder as the agent of change, stay free of corrupting corporate funding, and fight to raise all boats?
